article-meta.aff: 1Loma Linda University Medical Center, Loma Linda, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Camilla Cobb, Department of Pathology, Loma Linda University Medical Center, Room 2151, Loma Linda, CA 92345, USA Email: cobb@usc.edu

abstract.p: A dermoid cyst arising in the parotid is rare and usually represents the rare first branchial cleft type II anomaly, which can have morphology similar to a dermoid cyst. This study reports the case of a 20-year-old woman who presented with a parotid mass, which on histologic review was consistent with a dermoid cyst. This appears to be the first case report of a parotid dermoid cyst with focus on the gross and histopathologic findings and to be presented in a histopathology focused journal. The discussion includes the clinical presentation, imaging findings, gross pathology, histologic features, and differential diagnosis of parotid dermoid cysts. Although there was no prior fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the lesion in this case, parotid masses are commonly subject to FNA prior to excision. Therefore, a brief review of the FNA findings in dermoid cysts is also included.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A dermoid cyst, also known as a mature cystic teratoma, is a benign epithelial-lined cystic lesion containing mature elements from one or more of the 3 tissue germ layers (ie, mesoderm, endoderm, and ectoderm). It is usually diagnosed in a surgical specimen by its characteristic skin, hair, and sebaceous structures. Dermoid cysts can also contain other tissues, such as teeth, bone, cartilage, and thyroid, which is especially true with deep-seated dermoid cysts, such as those occurring in the ovary.

Although superficial dermoid cysts are not uncommon in the head and neck area, they are rare in the parotid gland, where in most cases they actually represent the rare first branchial cleft type II anomaly (FBCTIIA),1 which can be histologically similar to dermoid cysts. We were able to find 13 prior reported cases of parotid dermoid cysts, which cover a wide age range, with most presenting in adult males.2-12 With the exception of 2 case reports in a cytopathology journal,3 all cases were reported in surgical, radiology, or clinical medicine journals. Although none of the referenced reports of FBCTIIA13-24 stated that the lesion was a dermoid cyst or that it specifically resembled such, 2 reports did describe histologic features seen in dermoid cyst (ie, epidermal lining with pilosebaceous units in the wall).14,18 A few others reported a cystic lesion with a squamous lining 17,19,22,24 with no further characterization provided. The remaining reports of FBCTIIAs were described as draining inflamed cysts, abscesses, and sinus tracts or as cysts that were not otherwise characterized. Similar to the reports of parotid dermoid cysts, the listed reports of FBCTIIA were all reported in non-pathology journals. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first case of a parotid dermoid cyst to be reported in a histopathology-focused journal and with emphasis on the gross pathologic and histopathologic findings.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 20-year-old woman presented with a 2.5 cm painless, soft, and mobile right upper neck mass, which had been slowly enlarging over the course of 2 years. She denied any neurological symptoms, lymphadenopathy, fever, chills, or weight loss, and there was no history of prior surgery in the head and neck area.

A computed tomography scan showed a 2.0 × 2.0 cm hypodense mass in the region of the right parotid gland with a well-defined margin. A fat density signal was noted in the upper part of the mass, while the lower part displayed fluid density. The reported differential diagnosis on imaging included branchial cleft cyst and a dermoid cyst.

The patient underwent excision of the mass with partial parotidectomy, preserving the facial nerve. Following surgery, the patient experienced mild residual weakness in the lower lip. This subsequently improved, and the postoperative course has been otherwise uneventful.

sec.title: Pathology
sec.p: The specimen was submitted for frozen section. Sectioning of the gross specimen revealed a cyst containing blond hairs, oily and cheesy sebaceous material, and a recognizable strip of skin (Figure 1). The impression at this time was “dermoid cyst,” which was confirmed on frozen and permanent sections.

caption.p: Opened dermoid cyst containing hairs and oily sebum (gross)

sec.p: The histology showed benign parotid tissue and an adjacent benign cyst with an epidermal lining of keratinized stratified squamous epithelium (Figure 2) and pilosebaceous units in the underlying stroma (Figure 3). Foreign body granulomatous inflammation involved large areas of the cyst wall (Figures 2 and 4). In addition to anucleated squamous cells, the cyst contents on histology included portions of hair shafts and a few multinucleated foreign body giant cells (Figure 5).

caption.p: Dermoid cyst with underlying foreign body reaction and adjacent parotid (hematoxylin and eosin, 40×)
Dermoid cyst lined by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with underlying pilosebaceous units (hematoxylin and eosin, 100×)
Foreign body granulomatous inflammation in the cyst wall (hematoxylin and eosin, 400×)
Hair shaft and mutinucleated foreign body giant cell in cyst contents (hematoxylin and eosin, 400×)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Dermoid cysts, or mature cystic teratomas, are categorized as congenital lesions arising from rests of embryonic tissue and comprising one or more of the 3 germ layers. At least 7% of all dermoid cysts are found in the head and neck area, and over 80% of these are found in the orbital, oral, and nasal regions; presentation in the parotid is rare.25 Deep-seated dermoid cysts are found most often in the ovaries but also occur in the testes, mediastinum, and other sites and are also much more likely to show a wider variety of tissue types. The finding of teeth in ovarian dermoid cysts is particularly common. Peripheral dermoid cysts are typically lined by epidermis, with pilosebaceous units in the underlying stroma. The cyst contents include anucleated squamous cells and sometimes, as in the case presented here, sebum and hair.

True dermoid cysts of the head and neck typically occur centrally. Laterally situated dermoids, such as those presenting in the parotid, usually represent the rare FBCTIIA, which can be histologically similar to dermoid cysts but may also contain cartilage in the cyst wall.1 However, no cartilage was found in our case. In addition to, or instead of, a parotid mass histologically resembling a dermoid cyst, these patients may also present with a history of one or more of the following: recurrent abscess with an associated sinus orifice in the upper neck, frequent otorrhea, and sinus orifice in the ear canal floor.13-24 At surgery, FBCTIIAs usually have a juxta-auditory location and/or sinus track located close to the auditory canal and facial nerve.1,26 During her preoperative ear, nose, and throat evaluation, our patient’s only complaint was of a mass near the angle of the jaw, which was present for 2 years, and the physical examination revealed a normal pinna, external auditory canal and tympanic membrane, and intact overlying skin. The operative report detailed resection of the mass and superficial parotid, without mention of a sinus track or close situation of the mass to the auditory canal. However, in one large series of 39 cases, 23% of the FBCTIIAs presented as isolated cysts.24 It is likely that our case and the 13 referenced cases of parotid dermoid cysts represent the isolated cyst variant of the FBCTIIA, which features—as do superficial dermoid cysts—both ectodermal and mesodermal tissue (ie, skin and skin adnexa).1 For simplicity, in the remainder of this discussion parotid FBCTIIAs that resemble dermoid cysts will be referred to as dermoid cysts. However, in practice, when an apparent isolated parotid cyst with features of a dermoid cyst is submitted for pathologic evaluation, it is important that the pathologist communicates to the surgeon that the lesion likely represents a FBCTIIA, which will help ensure evaluation and treatment for other associated FBCTIIA lesions (eg, sinus tracks, inflammatory lesions).

For parotid dermoid cysts, the imaging findings may be nonspecific but typically show a well-circumscribed mass without invasion, which is helpful in establishing the nonmalignant nature of the mass in preparation for surgery. As in the case presented, imaging findings can on occasion be suggestive of a dermoid cyst when the oily sebaceous cyst contents convey a fat density appearance, with or without an associated fluid density in the dependent portion of the lesion. Indeed, in one other report of a parotid dermoid cyst the imaging suggested a lipoma.9 This information may be especially helpful for fine needle aspiration (FNA) diagnosis when imaging suggests a parotid lipoma and the FNA findings fit with a squamous lined cyst.

The gross finding of skin, hair, and sebum, as in the case presented, would be distinctive and characteristic of a dermoid cyst. When hair and/or adnexal structures are not apparent, the histologic differential diagnosis includes other squamous-lined cysts that can present in or near the parotid gland, such as branchial cleft cysts (BCCs) and lymphoepithelial cysts (LECs). Both BCCs and LECs feature significant lymphoid tissue in their wall and are usually lined by squamous epithelium and also sometimes, partly or solely, by columnar epithelium. However, their clinical settings differ. BCCs can present at any age, but the typical patient is a child or young adult with no other associated conditions. BCCs represent anomalies of the second branchial cleft and typically arise in the lateral neck anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, and they rarely present as a parotid mass. LECs are usually found in adults, and many patients are HIV positive, with LEC often being the initial manifestation of their HIV-positive status.27 An epidermal inclusion cyst is a skin-based (ie, superficial) lesion that may occur in the skin overlying the parotid following trauma or surgery. The cyst contents of an epidermal inclusion cyst comprise almost exclusively anucleated squamous cells, and in contrast to dermoid cysts, the underlying stroma lacks adnexal structures. Histology showing cyst contents that include squamous cells (mostly or exclusively anucleated) and sometimes hair, a cyst lining of benign epidermis, and underlying skin adnexal structures easily distinguishes a dermoid cyst from the entities noted above.

Fine needle aspiration is widely used to evaluate parotid masses preoperatively and has been reported as helpful in cases of parotid dermoid cysts, where aspiration of anucleated squamous cells and keratin debris pointed to the diagnosis of a benign squamous lined cyst.3 Interestingly, hair structures were apparently not found in any of the reported cases of FNAs of dermoid cysts.3,28-30 This may be because of the difficulty of aspirating hairs using a small gauge needle. Nevertheless, the above FNA findings in a non-skin-based lesion were suggestive of dermoid cyst preoperatively in the reported cases. Rendering a definitive diagnosis can be problematic when FNA yields anucleated and/or bland nucleated squamous cells and keratin debris. Even primary neoplastic and nonneoplastic salivary gland cysts (eg, simple cyst of the salivary gland duct, mucoepidermoid carcinoma, pleomorphic adenoma, Warthin’s tumor, etc) can have a variable amount of squamous metaplasia, which places them in the differential diagnosis of squamous lined cysts on FNA. Recognition of characteristic clinical, imaging, and morphologic features, such as oncocytes in Warthin’s tumor and chondromyxoid stroma in pleomorphic adenoma, is helpful for specific, or at least suggestive, diagnosis.

Cystic degeneration of squamous cell carcinoma metastatic to an intraparotid lymph node or a primary parotid cystic squamous cell carcinoma must always be considered when FNA findings fit with a squamous lined cyst, especially in older patients. Any squamous atypia would be suggestive but would usually require at least clinical correlation and/or histologic confirmation. Another lesion that may be in the FNA differential diagnosis of a squamous lined cyst is pilomatrixoma, a benign, skin-based solid lesion of hair matrix origin that is firm on palpation due to calcification and sometimes ossification and that usually occurs in children but can present at any age. A hard skin-based lesion yielding basaloid cells and “ghost cells” (ie, anucleated squamous cells) on FNA, particularly in a young person, would be characteristic of pilomatrixoma.31

As in the case presented, squamous lesions—both cystic and solid—may be associated with foreign body granulomatous inflammation, which occurs when host tissues are exposed to keratinaceous material. On occasion, the foreign body granulomatous inflammation can dominate and obscure the underlying lesion, especially in FNA samples, and an infection would need to be considered. Also, superimposed inflammatory changes can cause atypia that raises the possibility of malignancy when the squamous lesion is benign. Caution is especially needed in cytologic interpretation to prevent over diagnosis in benign lesions as well as a delay in the diagnosis of a malignant lesion, such as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Unless discriminating features are seen (eg, hairs, obvious malignant squamous cells), a descriptive diagnosis with suggestion of a specific lesion or a limited differential diagnosis is best, along with a recommendation to consider excision of the lesion for precise classification. Indeed, definitive diagnosis of a dermoid cyst is usually made on histology where benign skin and adnexal structures are easily identified.

Finally, malignant change in a superficial dermoid cyst is extremely rare and is almost always a squamous cell carcinoma.32 No malignancies in dermoid cysts of the parotid gland have been described to date, but this is an important consideration in the morphologic diagnosis of this lesion.
